sessions.title: Grafast: A Declarative Solution to GraphQL's Execution Woes
sessions.description: Introducing Grafast: a new approach to GraphQL execution, enabling engineers to build next-level efficiency into new or existing GraphQL APIs. This declarative approach to execution eliminates the many pitfalls of traditional resolvers and optimizes communications with your business logic. This is achieved through understanding the request's full data requirements and planning the best batched execution strategy before requesting anything from the business logic. This decoupling of data fetching from the GraphQL request shape results in fewer and more efficient operations against your backend services and data sources, eliminating both over- and under-fetching on the backend along with deduplication of redundant work, leading to reduced operational costs and delightful user experiences! A passion project of a founding GraphQL TSC member, this MIT-licensed open source technology has already been in production at a number of companies for over a year!

sessions.title: AI app cannot be tested — or can it? Exploring new frontiers in AI testing strategy
You and Yours Must Become Us and Ours
sessions.description: The skillq you possess are changing this world, however the skills necessary to effect change for good aren't going to be found in a programming manual. The reality of today's AI integrations means almost anything you do creates risk. Let's talk about the lessons from freeing ChatGPT and what it's done to the entire landscape of trust.

sessions.title: Hot Takes, Cool Planet: Debating AI Sustainability
Data Contracts: Treating Data as APIs
sessions.description: APIs brought order to software development through contracts, lifecycle management, and clear ownership. Yet in data, chaos often reigns: schema drift, silent breakages, and no shared language between producers and consumers. Enter the Open Data Contract Standard (ODCS)—an open initiative under the Linux Foundation that applies API thinking to data. Think of OpenAPI, but for data: a contract-first approach that enables robust data pipelines, clearly defined interfaces, and enforceable guarantees across teams. This talk will show how ODCS enables API-like discipline in data sharing, supports contract-driven development for data products, and introduces schema validation and lifecycle management into data workflows. These capabilities lay the foundation for scalable data marketplaces within organizations, making data assets discoverable, reliable, and reusable. As an outlook, we’ll explore the emerging Open Data Product Standard (ODPS), which builds on ODCS by grouping contracts into coherent, reusable building blocks. Together, ODCS and ODPS pave the way for a composable data architecture that aligns with data mesh and data-as-a-product principles.

sessions.title: Business Wants In—Here’s How to Drive API Wins (and Keep Your Sanity)
sessions.description:
It’s a common concern: when business teams get involved in APIs, IT worries about chaos, security risks, and added complexity. But IT’s traditional role as a gatekeeper can slow innovation and limit business value. With the right tools and governance, empowering business teams to build and manage APIs—no coding required—makes IT’s job easier, accelerates ROI, and drives agentic success, all while maintaining security and compliance.

Join this session to learn:

How business-led API initiatives drive measurable ROI and agility Why governance is essential for secure, scalable innovation Practical steps to enable business teams to build valuable APIs without code

Unlock innovation and business impact by putting API power in the hands of those closest to the outcomes.

sessions.title: AsyncAPI Bindings and Developer Experience
sessions.description: This approach turns an AsyncAPI specification into a fully executable contract test that verifies real event flows, not just schemas. I will walk through a practical example of how overlays allow teams to test end-to-end asynchronous workflows in a declarative, CI-friendly manner without relying on mocks, glue code, or environment-specific hacks.Attendees will leave with a clear understanding of how AsyncAPI can work together to close a long-standing gap in event-driven testing, making it possible to ship reliable, behaviourally correct event-based systems with confidence.

speakers.name: Swen-Helge Huber
speakers.jobtitle: Senior Director, Office of the CTO

sessions.title: Towards confidential AI
Beyond the pipes: Why Channel Management isn’t really commoditized?
sessions.description:
Channel management has been around for over 20 years. Born with the proliferation of OTAs in the early 2000s, it established itself as a cornerstone of the hospitality ecosystem.

Since then, hospitech has undergone a radical transformation: digitalization of hoteliers' daily operations, the emergence of alternative accommodations with Airbnb's arrival in 2009, and the multiplication of distribution channels worldwide.

Today, facing thousands of active OTAs globally, channel management might appear to be a basic, commoditized product. But this perception masks a far more complex reality.

Through the concrete case of Booking.com's "Seamless Experience," we'll explore how channel management continues to innovate in 2025: incremental optimizations, increasingly sophisticated integrations, and technical challenges that constantly push the boundaries of what seemed like a solved problem.

calendars.title: Travel Tech API Conference: Travel Unlocked!

sessions.title: The False Economy of Speed: Why Skipping API Governance Leads to Agentic Technical Debt
sessions.description:
The speed of agentic transformation is exciting, but pursuing it without strategic API governance is a dangerous, false economy. In the AI-driven enterprise, every ungoverned API becomes an escalating piece of agentic tech debt: exposing security vulnerabilities, hindering interoperability, and eroding your measurable business impact.

This session moves beyond basic API management. Join Markus Müller, Global Field CTO at Boomi, to learn how to eliminate architectural and organizational silos using an enterprise-ready platform. Transform your APIs from liabilities into trusted, strategic assets that accelerate, rather than undermine, agentic success.

Key takeaways for Enterprise AI and API leaders:

-Uncover the hidden costs of governance shortcuts, from architectural sprawl to agent-driven operational failure

-Learn how a unified platform enforces zero-trust principles and standardizes API definitions for rapid AI activation

-Focus on long-term business outcomes, proving governed speed is the path to sustainable ROI

Don't let the pursuit of speed derail your initiatives. Gain the strategic insights needed for a competitive, profitable, and lasting impact.

sessions.title: From APIs to Embedded Devices: Using JSON Schema even for Serial Protocols
sessions.description: Metadata management is the practice of cataloging, organizing, and maintaining information about data assets to ensure their accuracy, consistency, and usability. Traditionally, this has been achieved through the deployment of data catalogs, which provide centralized repositories for descriptive and structural information. In recent years, this approach has evolved to incorporate additional elements such as data lineage and standardized API descriptions, including OpenAPI and JSON Schema, to support greater transparency and interoperability across systems. Building on this comprehensive framework, we propose extending metadata management principles into the Internet of Things (IoT) domain by applying similar methodologies to W3C Web of Things (WoT) standards and JSON Schema. This advancement aims to enhance discoverability, reliability, and integration of IoT devices within broader data ecosystems.

sessions.title: Introducing Fission: The Intent-first Approach to Schema Design and Microservice Governance
sessions.description:
In today's complex microservice architectures, building cohesive APIs often feels like assembling a puzzle without seeing the complete picture. Traditional bottom-up approaches lead to fragmented schemas and governance challenges. This talk introduces Fission, a paradigm-shifting methodology that flips GraphQL Federation on its head.

Rather than building individual service schemas in isolation, Fission employs an intent-first approach where teams collaboratively design the ideal schema based on concrete use cases. This top-down methodology enables developers to create APIs that truly reflect business requirements while maintaining clean service boundaries.

We'll demonstrate how Fission abstracts away the complexities of federation, facilitates real-time schema collaboration, and introduces a governance model that evolves naturally with your architecture. Join us to discover how you can design like a monolith while implementing in a microservice architecture, all without sacrificing developer autonomy or API coherence.

sessions.title: From Zero to Spec-Hero: Eliminating Lean Wastes When Adopting OpenAPI
sessions.description:
Many organisations recognise the value of the OpenAPI Specification yet struggle to make it part of their everyday API delivery. In this session you’ll learn how to treat OpenAPI not as a checkbox, but as a Lean instrument for eliminating waste in API design, implementation and consumption. We’ll unpack the six major barriers that keep teams from transitioning, map each barrier to a Lean waste, and then walk through a practical adoption roadmap—starting from one API, embedding spec-first thinking, applying governance and tooling, and measuring the outcomes. If you’re ready to move from spec-ignored to spec-embedded, this talk shows you how.

3 Takeaways for attendees:

  1. A diagnostic checklist of common barriers to OpenAPI adoption and how they map to lean wastes.

  2. A phased transition roadmap—from legacy APIs or zero spec to full spec-driven delivery.

  3. Practical patterns: one-page spec governance, lightweight tooling integration (CI/CD tests + client generation), and how to show ROI in your organisation.

sessions.title: Using JSON Schema to generate JSON objects with LLMs
sessions.description: We present a novel application of JSON Schema: using it as a real-time contract for guiding Large Language Model (LLM) generation rather than merely for post-hoc validation. Our implementation achieves 100% schema compliance in production deployments across healthcare, autonomous agents, and data extraction. This work expands JSON Schema's utility beyond validation, positioning it as a bidirectional contract that controls both validation and generation, and suggests opportunities for formalizing generation-time usage patterns within the JSON Schema ecosystem.

sessions.title: Features You May Not Be Using (But Will Love)
sessions.description: We all know queries, mutations, and resolvers—but GraphQL has many other features. This session explores techniques you may not be using yet and will likely love once you do: directive‑driven concerns (auth, caching, validation) ; custom scalars that enforce domain rules at the schema edge; cursor‑based pagination that scales predictably; and thoughtful use of introspection. We’ll also cover designing stable, globally unique IDs that power robust cache keys.

sessions.title: Fluxnova - Open Source Process Orchestration
sessions.description: Overview of new opensource workflow engine Fluxnova and its capabilities, that helps business to develop and orchestrate end to end process by automating steps involved in a business workflow with multiple endpoints including both automated and manual steps. Fluxnova also helps to gain visibility and insights from automated process to identify and improve the bottlenecks. Join this session to learn more about Fluxnova and how new community of banks/Fintech companies neutrally governing and abandoned opensource project to grow and maintain it under FINOS/LF.

sessions.title: La marketplace s'enreichit : arrivée de Grist, évolutions d'Otoroshi et Keycloak
Lessons from Two Decades of Lifecycle Management: Governing APIs in the Age of AI
sessions.description:
In the age of AI and autonomous agents, APIs form the backbone of how intelligent systems understand, interact, and act on the world. The line between innovation and chaos now depends on how well we govern and evolve them.

Between us, Samir Amzani and Andrzej Jarzyna have spent decades making every imaginable API mistake - and learning from each one. From breaking production with unexpected changes to inheriting unmaintainable zombie APIs, we’ve seen what happens when lifecycle management and governance are overlooked.

API success isn’t about clean code - it’s about managing and governing its entire lifecycle with intent.

This talk distills the lessons that saved millions in developer hours and rebuilt trust across organizations.

You’ll learn:

  • Why most API failures happen after deployment - and how governance prevents them
  • How to evolve APIs safely without breaking consumers
  • How to identify and retire “zombie APIs” before they drain productivity
  • The design choices that help your API support both humans and AI agents
  • Why hypermedia and metadata-rich designs are key for machine understanding
  • Practical steps to make APIs discoverable, context-aware, and AI-ready
  • Deprecation strategies that maintain trust instead of chaos

Every insight comes from real-world scars: failed migrations, angry communities, and the realization that APIs are products requiring discipline, not one-off code drops.

You’ll leave with a practical playbook for governing APIs as living systems - ready for human developers today and autonomous agents tomorrow.

speakers.name: Andrzej Jarzyna

speakers.name: Samir Amzani

sessions.title: Designing Trusted Tourism Data for AI: The Scottish Approach
sessions.description:
Tourism generates large volumes of data, but too often it remains fragmented, locked in silos, or structured without reference to the values of the sector itself. In Scotland we’re experimenting with a different approach through the Scottish Tourism Data Partnership. Guided by the principles of the national tourism strategy; community empowerment, environmental care, sustainability, visitor management, and a thriving workforce; we are developing shared data infrastructure that reflects the priorities of the sector.

This session will introduce the design of Scotland’s tourism knowledge graphs as a foundation for interoperable APIs and explore how these could be linked into AI systems using the Model Context Protocol (MCP). The focus will be on practical pathways: how data can be structured and connected to allow destinations, operators, and developers to surface timely insights, create better visitor experiences, and manage impacts more effectively.

This talk will show how Scottish tourism organisations are working together to make collective tourism data more usable, trustworthy, and aligned with strategic goals. It will outline what this means for API developers, product teams, and travel technology partners who want to build systems that are not only technically powerful but also socially and environmentally grounded.

sessions.description: One form is easy to create and maintain. Come learn how JSON Schemas can become the SSoT (Single-Source of Truth) to manage your Forms at scale, filling the gap between any server and the browser without compromising the User Experience.

sessions.title: How the Dutch Government Uses an OpenAPI-First Approach to Leverage Developer Experience
sessions.description:
The Dutch government recently launched a new OpenAPI-first API Register, designed to make public sector APIs easier to discover, understand, and reuse. Unlike traditional catalogs, the register is built around OpenAPI specifications as the single source of truth. This enables automated validation, consistent documentation, and machine-readable contracts right from the start.

To further ensure quality and consistency, the register applies the Dutch API Strategy’s API Design Rules. These rules standardize everything from security schemes to error handling, so developers know what to expect when working with APIs from different ministries or municipalities. The result is a more predictable and streamlined developer experience.

The register also looks beyond single APIs. By supporting the emerging Arazzo standard, it can describe how multiple APIs interact to deliver complete government use cases — for example, registering a new business or applying for permits. This brings context and guidance to developers who need to orchestrate across domains.

Finally, the entire solution is open source. Other governments and large organizations can adopt or adapt it directly, benefiting from shared tooling and lessons learned in the Netherlands.

This talk will share how the OpenAPI-first approach, combined with standards like API Design Rules and Arazzo, helps scale interoperability, governance, and developer experience across the public sector.

sessions.title: Beyond PUE – Why Datacenter Efficiency is All About IT
From APIs to AI Agents: Architecting the Autonomous Enterprise
sessions.description: APIs gave enterprises the power to connect — now AI agents give them the power to autonomously decide. As organizations move from digital integration to digital intelligence, the next architectural frontier is autonomy: systems that learn, act, and optimize without human intervention. This session explores how to evolve an enterprise API ecosystem to support AI agents that can orchestrate complex workflows, trigger adaptive decisions, and expose new capabilities dynamically. To ground these ideas in practice, the session will include a live demo showing how an AI agent interacts with real APIs to execute an autonomous business scenario — integrating data, invoking services, and adapting behavior in real time.

What if we could turn these silos into a living ecosystem of collaboration and intelligence? In this talk, we explore how we can transform isolated services into interconnected, agentic platforms where data, APIs, and AI agents work together to power the modern enterprise. Join us for this hands-on deep dive and see how the future of connected systems is being built today.

Explore how deep understanding of traveler personas, preference prediction, and adaptive content generation work together to craft journeys that feel individually designed. A creative framework that makes travelers not just book, but know they belong.

sessions.title: Rethinking devportals, APIs and applications in the age of agentic AI: tools, spaces, and their affordances
sessions.description:
The agentic software pattern is opening up new ways to build applications. How will this affect developer portals? Will we still need to visit documentation portals, or will documentation sources become wrapped in an AI bot or documentation agent?

In this session, I will explore how distinguishing between applications acting like tools and applications acting like spaces can help us understand how things might develop. This will clarify where applications should be embedded into other applications as agents and where they should remain stand-alone applications.

I will then show that this trend is a continuation of a trend originally started by APIs and how it can help us create applications that adapt to their users. These applications can switch between unobtrusive tools that blend into a user's existing workflows or spaces that present an immersive context, depending on what is a better fit for any given job. This moves us away from an industry that has become over-dependent on tyrannical spaces that force users to constantly switch contexts or even become hostage to attention mining.

Attendees will learn the fundamental architecture required to create an intelligent AI that can independently pursue and achieve significant objectives.

sessions.description:
As API ecosystems grow, organisations must navigate the differences between developer portals, API catalogs, and marketplaces to optimise API consumer adaptation. Each of these components plays a unique role in the developer experience, but their responsibilities often overlap and it is easy to get confused regarding their purpose.

This talk breaks down the core functions of developer portals, API catalogs and marketplaces, explores their impact on API consumers, and provides guidance on when to use each. Consequently, organisations can make well-informed decisions about the tools anticipated by their customers.

sessions.description: For the past year, I've been working full-time in the JSON Schema ecosystem through my company Sourcemeta, partnering with enterprises to solve their most challenging schema problems. This hands-on experience has given me a unique perspective on where JSON Schema adoption breaks down at scale—from tooling limitations and governance challenges to organisational resistance and performance bottlenecks. In this talk, I'll share my pulse on the ecosystem, what I’m doing to fix it, and what the JSON Schema tooling of the future could look like.

sessions.title: Unlocking Performance with Response Caching
sessions.description: This talk reveals how unlocking cache benefits is now just a directive away: enable caching at the supergraph level, without touching your subgraph code. Take advantage of flexible surrogate cache keys for more granular invalidations, and enjoy instant improvements to performance and consistency across your federated graph without major architecture changes required. Debugging and operations become a breeze with the new cache debugger right inside Apollo Sandbox, enabling clear insights into cache behavior and hit rates. Deepened observability is built in, with expanded metrics and distributed tracing so you can understand, optimize, and trust your caching layer. When it comes to invalidation, it supports more complex invalidation scenarios—ensuring your data is always fresh and reliable. Learn how Apollo's latest caching rewrite offers a seamless path to higher performance, less backend load, and the observability teams need.

sessions.title: Agentic AI Is Here. Are You Ready to Govern It?
sessions.description: AI, particularly the rise of agentic systems, is proving to be one of the most disruptive technologies of our time, reshaping people, products, and processes across every sector. Yet alongside its transformative potential come new and distinctly challenging risks: hallucinations, inconsistency, limited explainability, and the difficulty of ensuring safe, secure, and compliant behaviour in real-world business environments. This talk explores how organisations can navigate these strengths and weaknesses in a balanced, pragmatic way, maximising value while applying the protective measures needed to meet regulatory expectations. As part of this, I will introduce the FINOS AI Governance Framework, showing how it can guide firms in managing AI responsibly and effectively.

sessions.title: From REST to Events: API Workflow Testing and Mocking with a Single Arazzo Spec
sessions.description:
APIs rarely work in isolation. Real-world usage involves multiple steps across both synchronous REST calls and asynchronous events, where the outcome of each step determines the journey a particular interaction takes. While testing individual endpoints is necessary, it’s not sufficient. It is equally important to validate how those endpoints and events work together as part of a real workflow.

Enter the Arazzo Specification V1.1, which describes complete workflows including inputs, outputs, step dependencies, and success/failure criteria, across OpenAPI (REST) and AsyncAPI (events). In this talk, we’ll demonstrate how you can leverage Arazzo to drive end-to-end API workflow testing and mocking in a completely no-code manner.

We’ll show how Arazzo + Specmatic enables shift-left testing of entire API journeys, spanning both sync and async operations. You’ll see how mocking complete workflows can unblock frontend teams, simulate event-driven flows, and accelerate CI pipelines. The session will also walk through the full lifecycle of how we design a multi-step journey, author or generate an Arazzo spec to capture it, and ensure both providers and consumers adhere to the same contract; thereby enabling independent, parallel development and deployment of services and components in complex, event-driven microservice architectures.

API as the powerful EA lighthouse for a Composable Information System
sessions.description:
Some say Enterprise Architecture is dead: it could not survive business, technology and organization fast changes. At the same time, Information Systems complexity has increased: an intricate mix of Cloud apps on the shelf, not-so-graceful old Monoliths and everything in between compose our current landscape. And with AI agents zooming-in as a new autonomous client of IT Systems, the need for efficient and actionable Enterprise-wide Architecture practice has never been so high.

Good news: we’ll see how API-first practices can be a lighthouse for continuous EA governance in action to tend towards some true Composable Information System management.

sessions.title: You may have OpenAPI, but is it AI-Ready?
sessions.description: I have worked with and reviewed thousands of APIs across startups, enterprises, and global platforms. Almost all shipped an OpenAPI Description. Yet through the lens of AI systems and intelligent agents, most failed a simple test. They were designed for humans (often badly), not machines. In this session I will share what I have learned from helping organisations make their APIs truly AI-ready, breaking down the six dimensions that determine whether an API can be understood, reasoned over, discovered, and safely executed by intelligent systems. These include foundational compliance, developer experience, semantic clarity, agent usability, security, and AI discoverability. Using the Jentic API Scoring Framework as a visual guide, I will show how to assess AI-readiness, where most teams stumble, and the simple changes that dramatically improve both human and machine understanding.

Last but not least, we'll present a way to expose your relational data into rich JSON Schema and JSON Documents, for example, to train your private AI models...

Come ready to rethink how JSON Schemas and databases collaborate in this API era!

sessions.description: In this session, TradeHeader will introduce the FINOS Common Domain Model (CDM) helping both business and technical participants with little or no CDM experience take their first steps toward building a CDM-based Java application. As co-creators of the model, we will outline the CDM’s purpose, governance, and core structures such as WorkflowStep, TradeState, and Payouts. We will show how they work through Java demonstrations of serialization, validation, and product qualification and highlight how state transitions like Execution or Termination formalize industry-standard events. The session will finish with pointers to the free FINOS CDM Course and source code to kick-start your CDM data journey.

sessions.title: Thinking Like a Pentester to Improve Your API Security
Structured Document Extraction with LLMs: From First Principles to Production
sessions.description:
Structured generation with LLMs makes it easier to extract standardized data from complex documents. But the process for building & evaluating the right schema is still largely artisanal. Retab has built an end-to-end platform for rigorously building these schema-driven pipelines. In this talk, Louis will go over technical insights and best practices.

He will cover the whole process:

  • Going from business problem to JSON schema
  • Context engineering for large documents
  • Designing evals for first-order and second-order extractions
  • Using k-LLM consensus to boost performance and quantify uncertainty
  • Retab’s agent for auto-optimizing JSON schema descriptions
  • Human-in-the-loop for schema-driven automations

sessions.title: How do you demo an API?
sessions.description:
You lost me at “terminal.” Does that sound familiar? You’ve just finished building your API product. Your boss wants to see how it works. The product team has been told to “expect great things.” You open your terminal, run curl, and... the demo’s over. Nobody cares. The value you’ve built is buried somewhere in a wall of JSON and standard output.

As someone who has spent the last 15 years building, launching, and demoing APIs for teams of all sizes, I’ve seen what works and what doesn’t when it comes to showing the true power of an API. Peter Cohan’s The Great Demo offers timeless lessons for product demonstrations, but how do those ideas translate to API products?

In this talk, we’ll explore how to communicate the real value of your API, whether it’s consumed through an MCP wrapper, a chat-based AI integration, or the next neobank spin-off. You’ll learn how to construct, present, and deliver a great API demo that resonates with both technical and non-technical audiences alike.

sessions.title: How to Fail Your Event-Driven System
sessions.description: So… what happens when you do it wrong? In this talk, we’ll explore the worst practices in event-driven systems—guaranteed to cause outages, data loss, and midnight debugging sessions. Whether you're a developer, architect, or C-level leader, you’ll walk away with battle-tested lessons on what not to do—and how to build systems that actually work.

sessions.title: An Eventful Journey: Building Federated GraphQL Subscriptions
sessions.description:
Real-time APIs are powerful - but making them work across a federated GraphQL architecture can quickly become a tangle of duplicated logic, performance bottlenecks, and inconsistent data. In this talk, we'll share how we evolved our GraphQL Federation from per-service subscription handling to a model where the federation gateway connects directly to an event system. This shift simplified the whole architecture and unlocked new ways to deliver consistent, scalable real-time updates across distributed microservices.

You'll learn:

  • How to design federated subscriptions that scale across services and teams
  • Practical strategies for dealing with eventual consistency and data freshness
  • Techniques to overcome performance bottlenecks like "thundering herd"
  • Advantages from running this architecture in production at scale

Whether you're designing your first federated GraphQL system or evolving one already in production, this session will help you rethink how event-driven patterns can make real-time APIs simpler, faster, and more resilient.

sessions.description: Specs like AsyncAPI set the stage, but true integration success depends on a shared language. This talk reveals how clear communication and aligned definitions can transform your APIs from sources of confusion into engines of business value. Learn practical strategies to bridge the language gap and build integrations that actually work.

sessions.title: Leading the Invisible Backbone: Managing API Teams in an Age of Platforms, Pressure & Product Thinking
What's All The Fuss About TypeSpec?
sessions.description: Ok, so you know OpenAPI and you love OpenAPI. You cannot imagine any other means to describe your APIs. You understand Operations Objects, Security Schemes, and the role Schema Objects play in well-described request and response payloads. You trust it, and so does your developer community. Enter TypeSpec, the new kid on the block for modelling APIs. In your ongoing love affair with OpenAPI, why should you care? In this session we'll take a look at TypeSpec from the angle of an ardent OpenAPI fan and look at what TypeSpec can actually do for you.

sessions.title: AI Product Journey: From Data to Decision
sessions.description:
AI Product Journey is a hands-on workshop where product leaders (POs, PMs, and beyond) learn to turn AI into a strategic ally rather than a black box.

Throughout a full day of collaborative sessions, you’ll learn how to:

Define the true purpose of your AI-enabled product and align AI with your business goals. Design responsibly by embedding AI Governance principles from the start. Identify and prevent biases or hallucinations that can undermine user trust and brand reputation. Balance innovation and risk, focusing on features that deliver measurable and sustainable value. Translate technical complexity into clear product decisions and communicate them effectively to your team and stakeholders. This workshop blends strategy, design, and serious play through visual tools, participatory exercises, and real-world simulations. You won’t learn to code AI—you’ll learn to lead it. (Because leading an AI product isn’t about understanding the algorithm; it’s about understanding its impact.)

sessions.title: AI and APIs: Ensuring Platform Migration Reliability with AI
sessions.description:
A major European Tech company is undertaking a major refactoring of its SaaS distribution platform, progressively migrating to a new orchestration architecture based on a standard API format. One of the main challenges of this transition is guaranteeing non-regression between the existing API and the new format, while limiting testing costs and migration risks for a platform distributing hundreds of millions of tickets annually.

To address this challenge, we explored AI-based solutions capable of analyzing massive JSON exposed by old and new APIs, identifying ""significant"" discrepancies for clients, and learning through iterations using agentic workflows and MCP (Model Context Protocol). This wasn't a smooth journey, but a true exploratory process with dead ends, unexpected problems, and valuable learning opportunities.

Beyond simple automation, this experience helped us build strong convictions about AI's contribution to complex architecture and concretely awakened our technical teams to the potential of AI.

sessions.title: Universal Interfaces: Turning Schemas into IDEs, UIs, CLIs and LLM Contracts
sessions.description:
Configuration files are now the primary UI for everything from Kubernetes to AI‑driven pipelines to new tools every day. And this trend has only accelerated in the AI era where everything wants to be text. But is text always the best interface? This talk shows how we can have our text and eat it too.

We'll explore how a single JSON Schema can be the single source of truth that unlocks the full spectrum of computer interfaces for both humans and machines:

  • an IDE experience (autocomplete, hover docs, validation)
  • a CLI validator (instant “‑‑check” style validation)
  • a UI generator (web forms, dashboards, wizard‑style editors)
  • an LLM contract (structured input/output for determinism)

... all without inventing a proprietary format or building custom tooling.

This talk walks through concrete approaches and tools to accomplish all this for JSON and YAML, plus we'll also take a look at KSON, which was designed around these exact principles with JSON Schema integration right at its core to facilitate creating and maintaining these Configuration User Interfaces.

sessions.title: Control Surfaces in OpenAPI: Designing Specs for Task, Plan, and Agent Modes
sessions.description: Your API is a control panel — but what controls should your OpenAPI specification expose? The answer depends on whether you're building for tasks, plans, or agents. A simple task needs input schemas and error responses. A multi-step plan requires lifecycle endpoints (pause/resume) and progress schemas. An autonomous agent demands budget parameters, approval callbacks, and emergency stop operations. Get the spec wrong, and you'll frustrate users trying to pause an atomic operation or micromanage a self-optimizing system. This talk explores how different AI operational modes—task, plan, and agent—require fundamentally different API control surfaces, and how to express these in OpenAPI. Through real-world specification examples and anti-patterns, you'll learn what endpoints, parameters, and schemas each mode needs, why mode mismatches cause design pain, and how to structure your OpenAPI specifications to expose the right level of control. Whether you're documenting a simple REST endpoint or a complex autonomous system, understanding control surfaces will help you design more intuitive and maintainable OpenAPI specifications.

sessions.title: Strategic APIs: Unlocking Value through Monetization, Security & Discoverability in the AI Ecosystem
sessions.description: I’m a Principal Engineer with over 12 years of experience in API strategy, integration architecture, and secure automation. At Shell, I lead enterprise-scale initiatives focused on leveraging APIs and AI to solve real-world engineering challenges securely and sustainably. I hold the CSSLP certification and specialize in API security, discoverability, and monetization across platforms like Azure (including AI Foundry), Power Platform (including Copilot Studio), Apigee, MuleSoft, and AWS. I also lead Shell’s internal AI Guild, driving experimentation and consultancy across 40+ engineers, and serve as the Efficiency Driver for GenAI and Copilot adoption. My perspective blends deep technical expertise with platform strategy, and I’m passionate about promoting API-first thinking, agentic architectures, and “consume-before-build” integration models.

sessions.title: Fluxnova Masterclass

From APIs to Workflows: Defining Travel’s Agentic Future Through Open Standards
sessions.description:
“It is not about the agent. It is about the workflow.” - Mckinsey & Co. This is the core reason most AI experiments in travel fail. Studies from MIT and McKinsey show the same pattern. Organisations are eager to use GenAI, yet very few succeed in production because agents cannot rely on the APIs available to them. Travel has a long history of APIs through OpenAPI, the OpenTravel Alliance schema, and partner integrations, but many of these APIs were never designed to express real use cases. Incomplete documentation, inconsistent structures, and missing business logic make it extremely difficult for agents to act safely across suppliers, partners, and systems.

This talk introduces the next layer of open interoperability: Arazzo, a workflow standard from the OpenAPI Initiative that captures the business logic behind travel operations, not just the endpoints. Arazzo provides a deterministic, testable, auditable way for agents to safely orchestrate multi-provider travel journeys; turning fragmented API landscapes into reliable, end-to-end workflows for itinerary changes, irregular operations, loyalty actions, refunds, and beyond. This is crucial as we move globally into the “context era” of interoperability, rapidly evolving from endpoints to use cases.

The future of travel automation will not be driven by smarter models, but by shared, open, deterministic workflows that make AI safe, reliable, and ready for production. And doing so leveraging open-standards, is the best bet!

sessions.title: GraphOps: Bringing DevOps to GraphQL with the Apollo GraphOS Operator
sessions.description:
GraphQL Federation, having multiple GraphQL services accessible via a single endpoint, is transformative for enterprises. Modular schema, decoupled deployments, and a clear ownership model can accelerate delivery by orders of magnitude. However, rolling out Federated GraphQL at scale comes with its own challenges, such as how to make deployments safe.

This talk will discuss the Apollo GraphOS Kubernetes Operator, a Kubernetes-native way for enterprises to manage GraphQL and Federation. It will start with general Operator design principles and discuss how these principles were applied to the Operator, so that it can address many different deployment strategiesuse-cases deployment architectures with multiple CustomResources. Attendees will also see how the Operator can perform safe deployments of GraphQL schema even in the face of a rollback.

In this talk, attendees will learn how combining GraphQL and DevOps can unlock the benefits of both approaches, all powered by the Apollo GraphOS Kubernetes Operator.

sessions.title: Spec-First API Designs Without Codegen
sessions.description: The talk is about keeping the two things that matter at the centre: The Users and the spec, the OpenAPI spec and how to design your code around it. It talks about the various real life challenges of not doing this and things like generating code and how popular opensource tooling can address this. It gives a practical way to approach this problem and work with teams at scale. This has already been presented at apidays London 2025.

sessions.title: Monetizing AI APIs
sessions.description: AI APIs are booming — but most developers and companies are still using primitive monetization models that either leave money on the table or break at scale. This talk uncovers how the new API economy needs to evolve to support the agent-driven future: usage-based pricing, digital worker metaphors, and the right infrastructure to support secure, trackable monetization. If we want the second wave of AI to thrive, we need to get serious about how we package, price, and present our APIs — especially when agents are the ones consuming them. This session is for product owners, API teams, and AI builders who are launching or managing AI-powered APIs. I’ll walk through real-world pricing patterns, show why API key leaks are a nightmare when billing is usage-based, and share an architecture using Amazon API Gateway + Stripe + API Portals that makes AI API monetization manageable. You’ll leave with a clear model for offering your AI APIs in a way that’s developer-friendly, secure, and ready for scale — whether you’re selling to other humans, or to autonomous agents.

sessions.title: From Chaos to Control: Applying Proven API Governance to the AI Era
sessions.description:
As enterprises rush to integrate generative AI into their digital ecosystems, many risk repeating the same mistakes of past technological revolutions — including prioritizing speed over control and failing to properly manage data across often disparate IT systems. With a rise in “agent anarchy” and shadow AI deployments, organisations must apply the same governance playbook they trust for APIs to the emerging world of autonomous agents and LLM integrations.

Emerging open standards, like Model Context Protocol (MCP) are making it easier for AI agents to securely discover, access, and interact with external tools and data sources through well-defined interfaces. By combining these interoperability gains with well-established practices from the world of API management — like data masking, throttling, and access control — organisations can responsibly scale AI-powered experiences. This session will provide a pragmatic framework for extending API-first thinking into AI environments, showing attendees how to leverage MCP and similar standards to avoid data leakage, maintain service quality, and reduce the risk of operational blind spots. Attendees will walk away with actionable insights for bringing stability to a fast-moving AI landscape using tools and principles already at their fingertips.

sessions.title: Reliable Kafka-Lambda Data Pipelines with AsyncAPI and Specmatic
sessions.description:
Event-driven architectures built with Kafka and AWS Lambda are increasingly popular for powering real-time data pipelines for analytics. However, ensuring reliable data transformations and compatibility between event-driven services presents two critical challenges: how to verify event schemas across isolated Lambda functions, and how to streamline local testing without continuous deployments to AWS.

In this talk, we’ll share practical lessons from real-world experiences building Kafka-Lambda pipelines. We’ll demonstrate how to model Kafka topics and event schemas clearly using AsyncAPI 3.0’s request-reply pattern. Then, leveraging Specmatic for automated contract testing, we’ll show how each Lambda function’s input-output compatibility can be rigorously verified in isolation. Lastly, we’ll highlight the use of LocalStack for rapid local development, significantly improving developer productivity and shortening feedback loops.

Attendees will walk away with a clear strategy and proven tools to: • Eliminate data schema compatibility issues before they reach production • Accelerate the development process through effective local testing • Build robust, contract-driven Kafka-Lambda integrations using AsyncAPI and Specmatic

Join us to unlock the full potential of reliable, maintainable, and developer-friendly real-time event-driven data pipelines.

sessions.description: An introduction to how JSON Schema fakers work, what goes into them, why you might want to use one, weird and wonderful edge cases involved in doing so. And challenges yet to be faced. Based on ongoing with the https://github.com/ryanolee/go-chaff project.

sessions.title: More Than Carbon: What's the Environmental Footprint of Nvidia Chips Powering AI?
Beyond SDL: Into the Wonderful World of Graphs
sessions.description:
GraphQL says “graph,” but SDL keeps us in text. In this talk, we step beyond SDL into the wonderful world of graphs. I will show how layout choices affect readability and we explore why hierarchical (Sugiyama-style) diagrams can beat force-directed “hairballs.”

Drawing on lessons from building GraphQL Voyager, I’ll share quick visual experiments and practical heuristics—simplifying connections, collapsing low-signal nodes, separating operation roots. I’ll also present emerging interactions for large, GitHub-scale schemas.

You’ll leave with a grounded view of the possibilities and limits of graph visualization, plus sneak peeks at new experiments I’m working on.

sessions.title: Future Direction: Embedded Finance and Smart Data
sessions.description: Embedded Finance and Smart Data are transforming the financial and tech sectors, opening new opportunities for integration and value creation. Embedded Finance involves seamlessly integrating financial services—such as payments, lending, insurance, banking, and investing—within non-financial platforms like e-commerce, healthcare, and ride-sharing apps, driven by robust APIs. This approach meets users where they are, offering effortless experiences and building customer loyalty. For instance, platforms like Shopify, Lyft, and Tesla provide embedded banking, instant payments, and in-app insurance, changing how people and businesses engage with financial products. The rise of Smart Data enhances this ecosystem by enabling real-time insights and personalized options through advanced analytics and consent-based data sharing. By utilizing open banking standards, APIs, and large-scale data aggregation, companies can develop highly personalized services and unlock new revenue streams, while consumers gain from increased financial inclusion, tailored recommendations, and smoother transactions. This presentation will examine the technical and strategic advances driving Embedded Finance and Smart Data, emphasizing their influence on user experience, business models, and the evolving API landscape. Grasping these trends is essential for developers, fintech innovators, and digital leaders seeking success in the connected finance era.

sessions.title: OpenAPI and Spring-Boot 4 - What's New?
sessions.description:
Spring Boot remains the most widely used Java framework for modern application development, powering millions of applications globally. With Spring Boot 4, the framework enters a new era of performance, cloud-native support, and developer productivity. This talk will showcase the key innovations in Spring Boot 4 — including built-in API versioning, improved performance and integrations, — that make it a powerful choice for building scalable APIs.

A major focus will be on OpenAPI and its integration via springdoc-openapi, a community-driven project that now exceeds 30 million downloads per month. We’ll dive into the core features of springdoc-openapi, including support for Scalar project in addition to swagger-ui, Spring MVC, WebFlux, GraalVM, Kotlin. You'll also learn how to leverage advanced features like actuator integration, Javadoc reuse for API descriptions, HATEOAS, Data REST, and OAuth2 security.

The session will also cover historical version support in Spring Boot, illustrate how OpenAPI is transforming the developer experience, and explore modern tooling for CI/CD pipelines with Gradle/Maven for API documentation generation. We'll also touch on microservices use cases with Spring Cloud Gateway and serverless integration with Spring Cloud Function.

Whether you're modernizing legacy APIs or building greenfield microservices, this session offers practical insights and resources to accelerate your API-first development journey.

sessions.title: Using the Power of APIs and Domain Driven Design to Embrace AI While Protecting your Pocket
Evolving JSON Schema: Progress, Gaps, and the Road Ahead
sessions.description: In this talk, I’ll share a candid update on the evolution of JSON Schema—what’s working, what’s missing, and where we’re headed next. Drawing from my experience leading community coordination and engagement, I’ll reflect on the milestones we’ve reached, the challenges we’re tackling, and how collaboration continues to shape the project’s growth. From tooling updates to community-driven initiatives, this session highlights how we’re building a more resilient, inclusive ecosystem, and why every contributor’s participation matters in shaping the next chapter of JSON Schema.

sessions.title: Fluxnova Masterclass
AsyncAPI + Overlays: Testing Event Flows with Triggers and Side-Effects
sessions.description: Testing event-driven systems is fundamentally harder than testing REST APIs. Validating schemas is straightforward, but validating behaviour in terms of what the system actually does when it receives or produces an event is still a major challenge. Teams often struggle to trigger their systems reliably, observe side-effects, and automate end-to-end event flow testing without custom scripts or brittle harnesses.In this demo, I will introduce a new capability in Specmatic that brings executable behaviour into the AsyncAPI ecosystem. Using a simple Overlay file, engineers can define.

sessions.title: Is OpenAPI still relevant in the age of AI?
sessions.description:
Count the times when you said “OpenAPI” and others heard “OpenAI”…

Just when API Design, machine-readable API documentation, and OpenAPI have finally been normalized and gained traction, AI and agents throw a wrench into the works.

At a time when you can vibecode an API in minutes and instantly stand up an MCP server, how useful is it to write and maintain OpenAPI documents?

Join me to examine where and how OpenAPI remains relevant for your organization & product delivery and where it’s no longer that useful (and what we could do instead).
